conclusion: Displacement is the integral of velocity over time, which corresponds to the area under the v-t graph.
For each car, the displacement during t = 0 to t = t1 is equal to the area enclosed by its respective v-t curve and the time axis.
Car A starts at velocity v2 at t = 0 and decreases linearly to velocity v1 at t = t1.
The graph for Car A forms a straight line sloping downward, creating a triangular area under the curve.

premise: Car A starts at velocity v2 at t = 0 and decreases linearly to velocity v1 at t = t1.
conclusion: The area (displacement for Car A) can be calculated using the formula for the area of a triangle: Area for Car A = 1/2 × base × height.
Base = t1 (time interval), Height = v2 - v1 (difference in velocity)
Displacement for Car A = 1/2 × t1 × (v2 - v1)
Car B starts at velocity v1 at t = 0 and increases linearly to velocity v2 at t = t1.
The graph for Car B forms a straight line sloping upward, creating a triangular area under the curve.

premise: Car B starts at velocity v1 at t = 0 and increases linearly to velocity v2 at t = t1.
conclusion: The area (displacement for Car B) can also be calculated using the formula for the area of a triangle: Area for Car B = 1/2 × base × height.
Base = t1 (time interval), Height = v2 - v1 (difference in velocity)
Displacement for Car B = 1/2 × t1 × (v2 - v1)

premise: Displacement for Car A = 1/2 × t1 × (v2 - v1), Displacement for Car B = 1/2 × t1 × (v2 - v1)
conclusion: Both expressions are identical, meaning the displacements of Car A and Car B are the same during the time interval t = 0 to t = t1.
